properties.Title: Stirrup Cup in the Form of a Fox's Head
properties.Desc_title: Stirrup cup in the form of a fox’s head
properties.Desc_text:
Thomas Pitts I, 1771. Silver with traces of
gilding and gilded interior, 6 ×
8 × 14 cm (2 3/8 × 3 1/8 × 5 1/2 in.).
Harvard Art Museums/Fogg
Museum, Paul Clarke Stauffer
Fund, 2012.6.
properties.Credit: © President and Fellows of Harvard College

properties.Title: Drinking horn (“griffin claw”)
properties.Desc_text:
German (Nuremberg), 1436
CE
Bovine horn with gilded
silver mounts
24.2 × 31.9 × 12.6 cm (9 1/2 ×
12 9/16 × 4 15/16 in.)
Inscribed: Herr Johann
Freiherr von Haideck verehrt
Burgermeister und Rath zu
Haideck mit diesem
Trinkgeschirr anno 1436 (This
drinking vessel was given by
Baron Johann von Heideck to
the mayor and counsel of the
town of Heideck in 1436). Private collection; courtesy of the
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New
York, L.2015.77.
properties.Credit: © The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Image source: Art Resource, NY

properties.Title: Ceremonial Drinking Horn
properties.Desc_text:
Cameroon Grassfields,
Bamum Kingdom, early 20th
century CE
Buffalo horn, glass beads,
fiber, and cotton cloth
Length: 41 cm (16 1/8 in.);
diameter: 15.5 cm (6 1/8 in.)
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New
York, The Michael C. Rockefeller
Memorial Collection, Bequest
of Nelson A. Rockefeller, 1979,
1979.206.34.
properties.Credit: © The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Image source: Art Resource, NY

properties.Title: Ceremonial Drinking Horn
properties.Desc_text: Bamum Kingdom, Grassfields region, Cameroon, early 20th century CE. Buffalo horn and camwood powder,  21 × 36.8 × 7.6 cm (8 1/4 × 14 1/2 × 3 in.). Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Fletcher Fund, 1972, 1972.4.63
properties.Credit: © The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Image source: Art Resource, NY

properties.Title: Drinking Horn
properties.Desc_text:
Georgian, c. 1960 CE
Bovine horn, silver, and
niello
Length: 34.8 cm
(13 11/16 in.); diameter:
8.4 cm (3 5/16 in.). 
John. F. Kennedy Presidential
Library and Museum, Boston,
Gifts from Heads of State, MO
63.2470.1
properties.Credit: Courtesy of the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum, Boston. Photo by Joel Benjamin

properties.Title: Rhyton with a centaur holding a goat
properties.Desc_title: Rhyton with a centaur holding a goat
properties.Desc_text:
Perhaps
Saka, late 1st millennium
BCE. Bronze and copper, height:
27.5 cm (10 13/16 in.); diameter: 16.4
cm (67/16 in.). From Gilgit (Pakistan).
Ashmolean Museum of Art
and Archaeology, University of
Oxford, EA1963.28.

properties.Title: Frieze of Five Dancing Women, Vase Decorated with Male Heads, Rhyton with a Bull’s Head, Statue of a Child Milking a Goat, Anubis Seated
properties.Desc_title: Frieze of Five Dancing Women, Vase Decorated with Male Heads, Rhyton with a Bull’s Head, Statue of a Child Milking a Goat, Anubis Seated
properties.Desc_text: Jean-Claude Richard, Abbé de Saint-Non, French, 1727–1791, after Hubert Robert, French, 1733– 1808., 1763 CE. Etching Plate: 32.2 × 22.4 cm (12 11/16 × 8 13/16 in.). Harvard Art Museums/Fogg Museum, Anonymous gift, M23213
properties.Credit: © President and Fellows of Harvard College

properties.Title: Diana and stag automaton
properties.Desc_text:
German. 1610–20 CE. Cast and chased
silver, partially gilded and painted
with translucent lacquers, height:
33 cm (13 in.); width: 25.4 cm
(10 in.). Museum of Fine Arts,
Boston, Museum purchase with
funds donated anonymously and
the William Francis Warden
Fund, Frank B. Bemis Fund,
Mary S. and Edward Jackson
Holmes Fund, John Lowell
Gardner Fund, and by exchange
from the Bequest of William A.
Coolidge, 2004.568.

properties.Title: The Women of Amphissa
properties.Desc_text:
1887. Oil on canvas, 122.5 ×
184.2 cm (48 1/4 × 72 1/2 in.). Clark
Art Institute, Williamstown,
Massachusetts, 1978.12.
properties.Credit: © Sterling and Francine   Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts. Photo by Michael Agee
